content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" may be cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President to submit the budget, the Congressional Budget Office to submit a report, committees to submit views and estimates, Budget Committees to report a concurrent resolution, Congress to complete action on the resolution, and the consideration of appropriation bills in the House. The congressional budget process includes deadlines for completing action on reconciliation legislation, biennial appropriation bills, and defense appropriation bills by specific dates such as June 15, June 30, August 1, and October 1 when the fiscal year begins. During the first session of Congress following a leap year, if a new President takes office, specific dates will change. The timeline for budget-related actions in Congress includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports from the Congressional Budget Office, committee submissions, and completion of actions on the budget resolution. Additionally, specific dates may change during the first session of Congress following a leap year if a new President takes office. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills, including the defense appropriation bill and reconciliation legislation. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Military Construction, Veterans Affairs. In even-numbered years, Congress follows the budget process to consider appropriation bills. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for various departments. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define a biennium as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations for appropriations are adjusted to cover all fiscal years in the resolution, including defense funding. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include defense funding for each fiscal year in the biennium. This adjustment covers all fiscal years in the resolution and specifies the total of all fiscal years covered. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code include defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following 4 years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following 4 years, including changes to tax expenditures and future years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following 4 years, including changes to tax expenditures and future years. The amendments include updating prior year outlays and receipts to cover the 2 most recently completed fiscal years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following 4 years. This includes updating prior year outlays and receipts to cover the 2 most recently completed fiscal years. Changes are made to estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches, as well as recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following 4 years. This includes updating prior year outlays and receipts to cover the 2 most recently completed fiscal years. Changes are made to estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches, as well as recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies. Section 1105(e)(1) of title 31, United States Code is amended to adjust the capital investment analysis terminology for the biennium budget. SEC. 5. TWO-YEAR APPROPRIATIONS; TITLE AND STYLE OF APPROPRIATIONS ACTS. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will have a specific format for each fiscal year in a biennium, while defense Acts will be titled for the fiscal year. All Acts making regular appropriations must include specified amounts. The Government's support specifies appropriations for each fiscal year in a biennium. Definitions for terms like 'biennium' are provided in accordance with relevant Acts. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the table of sections in the United States Code. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless the project will be completed with the funds. It also restricts authorization or revenue bills until Congress completes budget resolution and appropriations bills. In the Senate, exceptions apply to defense and privileged measures. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless the project will be completed with the funds. It also restricts authorization or revenue bills until Congress completes budget resolution and appropriations bills. In the Senate, exceptions apply to defense, privileged measures, matters considered in Executive Session, or appropriations measures/reconciliation bills. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT requires joint oversight hearings on agency activities not funded under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The hearing reviews agency mission, impact of biennial budgeting, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs. SEC. 8. REPORT ON TWO-YEAR FISCAL PERIOD is also included. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will study the impact of changing to a 2-year fiscal period with a biennial budget process and submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations for the biennium starting in fiscal year 2017.
